DOC.HEAD: Invasion Legal Under U.S., International Law, Administration Says
Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to include comment from Yale law professor.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush adminstration argued Wednesday that the U.S. invasion of Panama was legal under both domestic and international law but some lawyers who have tried war-powers cases disagreed. Secretary of State James Baker cited Article 51 of the United Nations Charter that gives nations the right to act in self-defense and a similar provision of the Organization of American States treaty as the legal basis for the invasion. Article 21 of the OAS treaty gives the United States the right to protect its citizens, installations and institutions, the secretary said. Baker also cited the terms of the Panama Canal Treaty that give the United States the right to exercise force to protect the canal to keep it operating. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh advised President Bush about the legality of the operation before it was launched, said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel. Thornburgh ``believes there is a legal basis for this action being taken under U.S. law,'' Runkel said. ``It is my understanding there is clearly legal authority under both U.S. law and international law.'' But two attorneys for the Center for Constitutional Rights, a liberal New York-based civil liberties group, disagree. `I'd say it's clearly illegal under the UN Charter and the OAS charter,'' said attorney Jules Lobel, who is also a law professor at the University of Pittsburgh. ``The United States doesn't have the right to unilaterally decide to overthrow another governent by the use of force,'' Lobel said. ``Nothing that the president said today or the secretary of state said would give the the United States such a right.'' Lobel said the United States must show it is acting in self-defense for the invasion to be legal under the UN Charter and the OAS treaty. ``I don't think that can be based on some speculated threat that American citizens might be endangered,'' Lobel said. Baker had cited an intelligence report that Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noreiga was poised to attack Americans. ``If American citizens might be endangered, the obvious thing to do is to protect them and evacuate them not overthrow the government,'' Lobel said. Both Lobel and David Cole, another attorney for the center, said the invasion also violated the war-powers provision of the Constitution, which requires congressional approval of the deployment of troops in this fashion. ``I think the intent of the framers of the Constitution is clear, if the United States is going to offensively use military force abroad it must be approved by Congress and not by four leaders in Congress,'' Lobel said. ``As a purely technical constitutional matter, the president does not have the authority to do what he did,'' Cole said. ``As a matter of legal and political reality, if Congress doesn't try to stop him, I think it's unlikely the courts would.'' Yale University law professor Harold Koh voiced caution about the invasion, saying ``the rationale of protecting the securityof the canal must be limited to making sure there is no damage to the canal or some impairment of the security of the canal.'' ``It can't be an all-purpose justification of wide-ranging actions to restructure the government,'' Koh said. Koh also expressed skepticism about justifying the invasion as an effort to arrest Noriega. ``As a matter of international law, there is a danger in converting political action into so-called crime fighting action.''
